sen.j: 土豪（どごう）とは、広義には広域を支配する領主や在地の大豪族に対して、特定の「土地の小豪族」をさす。
sen.e: Dogo, in a broader sense, refers to 'smaller regional clans' in contrast with larger regional clans which rule broader area.
In a broad sense, dogo refers to specific small local clans as opposed to large regional clans which control wide territories.

sen.j: 土豪という用語は、室町・戦国期に頻出する歴史用語であるが、大和朝廷時代の歴史用語として、地方首長である国造層を指す語としても使用されている。
sen.e: Dogo is a history term which frequently appears to the history of Muromachi and Sengoku period and it also refers to 'Kuni no miyatsuko' (regional officers) at the time of Yamato period.

Dogo is a historical term that frequently appears in relation to the Muromachi and Sengogu (warring states) periods but when used in reference to the period of Yamato dynasty, it refers to kuninomiyatsuko (provincial governor) class of local heads.

sen.e: Dogo in a narrower sense means weaker samurai with small power, given that the separation between soliders and farmers took place.

sen.j: また、広義の場合には、豪族（大豪族）が中央から下ったか在地かはともかく、その地域で、数郡を支配する大勢力を有したのに対し、一般にその傘下にあるか、あるいは独立した在地の数村を支配する小規模の豪族である、地頭やその系譜をひく国人領主の家臣或いは被官たる者で地侍の主筋になる在地領主をも含む概念。
sen.e: Dogo in a wider sense includes Zaichi Ryoshu, the lords of the manors of Ji-zamurai, who served Jito (land stewards) or Kokujin (Jito's descendants), who were under the rule of large Gozoku (powerful families) or who were small Gozoku who owned a couple of independent villages, in contrast to the large Gozoku who governed large discricts in the regions aside from whether they came from the center or not.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味が不明です。また国人（原文、リンク先の語）を国人領主（本来のものと思われる語）として訳しました。
sen.e: In wider sense, the term includes jito (managers and lords of manors), kokujin (local samurai) vassals descended from jito, or feudal lords who were hikan (low-level bureaucrats) descended from jizamurai; which were all small gozoku (local ruling families) affiliated with large gozoku or were independent and controlled several villages in the area as opposed to large gozoku which either came from central government or were based in the area and possessed the great influence of controlling several districts.
sen.cmt: Poor translation. Retranslated to relect source text.
sen.e: In wider sense, while larger gozoku (local ruling families) had a large power to reign some counties in his assigned region whether he stayed in the center or the local, dogo was a retainer or hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of jito, who were usually smaller gozoku and reigned some villages which were under control of or independent from the larger gozoku, or kokujin ryoshu (local samurai lord) of the jito's linage, and even included zaichi-ryoshu (local lord) which was to be the main stream of jizamurai.
